												Despite the fact I had tons of fun playing this game, it will be the only Prince of Persia I don't recommend, and I don't recommend it for two reasons:First off, it's not a Prince of Persia game. I get that they were trying to go new character, new kind of story, but really for all the differences between it and the feel of the games in the Sands of Time series, (which this is supposed to resemble), it really just has success by loose association. The platforming looks similar, but feels completely different. Plus, there is absolutely NO way to die. You have a partner with magic powers who will use them to catch you if you fall, push enemies off you before they can deliver deathblows, and pull you out of slime. This turns mistakes into minor inconveniences, instead of a need to restart. In the Sands of Time series, you could stop yourself from dying, but every time you use the Sands means that there's one less mistake you can make somewhere else. In this, Elika has seemingly unlimited power. This means you get unlimited restarts. You go back to the last place with solid ground. The enemy gets back the last round of damage you dealt to it. I think every element of this game is great and that they were all mixed together well. However, at the same time, it didn't feel like a challenge in the slightest. Even the Warrior, who you had to button mash to defeat and if you didn't send him over the edge he'd send you through the floor, never once stood a chance because you could survive ANYTHING thanks to Elika. On the topic of the Warrior, let's talk about the battle system. You had five main enemies to face, and some smaller soldiers along the way. The battle system was rebuilt around the fact you couldn't die. It was a fun battle system, but again it wasn't the free-form battle system I had come to expect from Prince of Persia. Yes, there were combos, but you really couldn't choose your own battle style. There were only two combos that did large amounts of damage: 4 sword strikes, or elika, elika, grapple, jump, elika, sword. Everything else was either there to push enemies into things, or the combos were just too short for damage to add up. Ubisoft could make a killing on a game based around this concept, but I wouldn't call it a Prince of Persia game and the system needs major refinement. Now, for the second thing I didn't like about the game: Story. Until the final sequence at the Temple, I thought it was fine. The intro was a bit weak, but hey, not every game deserves a cinematic. However, this is Prince of Persia. Ubisoft has made the whole series around a theatrical experience, and then they suddenly killed it in this one. Again, I get they were trying to go new hero, new kind of experience, but, as much as I like to bash Call of Duty for not innovating, They at least know that people like to play games with the same title for the same sort of experience. They changed this one a bit too much from the Sands of Time formula. Anyway, back to my problems with the plot. Other than the intro and the ending, it was actually fine. You had four different areas to explore and you could do them in whatever order you wanted. The plotline was built in such a way that it didn't matter which one you went to first. That was nice. However, I had to restart the game at one point because of a thoughtless error on Ubisoft's part. It didn't matter which power you unlocked first. However, the one that you choose second pretty much has to be the one that lets you progress further into the same area you were just in. Which means that you have to face down one boss at a time, four, maybe five times in a row. They make him "harder" every time, but it doesn't make a difference because you can't die. I had to restart the game because I chose the wrong second power. The Hunter in my opinion was the easiest to defeat, so I wanted to save him for last. However, becaue I chose to fight him after gaining my first power, it meant I couldn't possibly get enough pickups from the areas I had access to to unlock the third power. This forced me to COMPLETELY RESTART THE GAME!!! Now, I'm gonna try and talk about the ending without any spoilers. The whole game (when I played through the way Ubisoft wanted me to) had a pretty nice flow. You couldn't really get lost unless you found a way to skip cutscenes. So here's pretty much how it goes: weak beginning, good flow, good flow, good flow, good flow, mostly stable climax, panicked platforming sequence, then WTF? As far as I can tell I didn't accidentally choose an alternate ending. Your unnamed character undoes everything you worked so hard for the whole game, and it's not even like one of those "rewind" endings. If it was, I might not be so upset. This was an ending where he saves the world, changes his mind, and then ends it. Thanks a lot, Ubisoft! I thought this was supposed to be a reboot. How are you supposed to return to a world that NO LONGER EXISTS????I had fun. I'd probably play again. I just couldn't justify this to someone unless they enjoyed this kind of plot.

												I got Prince of Persia 4 (the 2008 'reboot') in a pack with the other PoP games for $10. It seems safe to say I've got my monies worth. Although this one lacks the sheer "wow factor" that the first PoP had upon its release, the 2008 reboot does ambiously innovate in its own ways. There are gameplay mechanics that will frustrate, even irritate you at times, and by the end of the 15 hour campaign it begins to border on repetitive--but other aspects of the game really stand out. Amongst these are the unique water-colour graphics, the incredible sound-track (one of the best I've ever heard), the excellent voice-acting, and an exceptional ending; probably in my personal 10 best of all time. I don't want to give anything away, but it had me thinking, and that's something few games accomplish these days. It's not the best game I've played in the last year, but it does some things better than most, and it is one of the most ambitious and unique, something that I respect in an increasingly saturated "appeal to the lowest common denominator" market. Thank you Ubisoft Montreal (makers of  Assassin's Creed) for taking that chance. The gaming industry needs developers to take more chances on games like this, even if they aren't a complete success in every regard. If you get the chance, pick it up. You'll be supporting creativity, and treating yourself to a pretty excellent game too. 8.2/10.

												'Big bad' God Ahriman is breaking out of his tree-prison and covering sidekick Elika's kingdom with 'corruption'. To put the cork back in his bottle you must bust out your very choicest pakour and cleanse all of the 'fertile lands' across the impracticality designed kingdom. For reasons that may or may not involve Elika's hip to waist ratio, our #Edgy Prince decides to tag along. 	You're left to explore a relatively non-linear overworld. You're free to choose in what order to clear levels, but ultimately they must all be cleared and they all follow an identical structure. Climb to fertile land, fight boss, cleanse land. All too quickly, you settle into this routine, and the cycle goes unchallenged throughout the entirety of the game. So much so that you get diminishing returns; no matter how satisfying it is at first to return a fertile ground to it's prettier, greener version, after cleansing 20 areas they all begin to blend into one and each feels less rewarding than the last.	Levels do their best to stand out. Sometimes the stage's boss will interfere, flooding the level with corruption, destroying structures around you or polluting the air. This would've added texture to the game but none of it ever has any impact on gameplay, and amounts to nothing more than decoration. Nonetheless, during these sections Elika and the Prince will dutifully play along with the developers, acting as though these facades are serious issues.	You can't die, Elika will save you no matter how bad you ♥♥♥♥ up. This completely undermines any potential tension. My play style soon veered towards recklessness as there was no reason to be attentive or careful, mistakes are never punished. On the other hand, this feature means the flow of the game is uninterrupted and creates a relaxed and pleasant mood when parkouring across the land.	Combat is stiff. You never deal with more than one opponent at a time. The prince has suddenly lost all acrobatic ability and is fixed to the ground, confined to four attacks and combos. Compare to The Sands of Time wherein combat was more intrinsically linked to the prince's parkour abilities, and there was often space to get creative when tackling many foes. The combos look great though, and parrying attacks is satisfying if sometimes unreliable. When you screw up and need Elika to save you the enemy regains health meaning if you're struggling these fights can go on for a long time. 	Once you've cleared a level, 'light seeds' appear across that level, requiring you to backtrack through the area once or twice to gather them. Despite the transparent effort to extend the game, the most immersive platforming takes place during these searches. Unlike the mindless tunnel platforming throughout the rest of the game, you must occasionally pause, examine your environment and plan your actions. You'll require exponentially more and more of these seeds to unlock four-colour coded powers that each unlock access to more fertile grounds. Unfortunately the powers are indistinct and unsatisfying to use. 	The red and blue powers are identical and simply propel you from a suitably colour-coded plate to another point (usually another plate). The green power is the most fun, propelling the prince in a straight line up and across walls and ceilings, leaving it to the player to strafe left and right to avoid oncoming obstacles. By far the most obnoxious part of the game, the yellow power propels you into a stiffly-animated on-rails 'flight' around the map on the longest route conceivable to man. If you can see through the ugly obtrusive special affects that border your screen you must dodge corners of buildings and whatever other last-minute obstacles the developers decided to try to run you into. Other times it blissfully propels you across short distances... so works exactly like the red and blue powers again.	Elika handles world building exposition throughout a frequent scattering of cut-scenes, explaining what the different sections of the kingdom were supposedly used for before they became interchangeable slip'n'slides. Her descriptions are inconsistent, vague and fail to lend any much-needed depth to the setting. Character development based dialogue and exposition are confined mostly within optional dialogue snippets available at the press of a button. 	This is an odd way round to do things since the narrative success of the story hinges on you developing an attachment to Elika, and so character development should be the primary focus. Regardless, initiating a conversation on your own terms is fairly immersive and I only wish that the feature had been used more widely to reduce the number of expositional cut-scenes that break the flow of play.	The final battle is much like any other stage, unsurprisingly. The game's narrative twist lies in (SPOILER ALERT) forcing the same choice upon the Prince as Elika's father when he brought her back to life at the cost of freeing Ahriman in the first place. This was a nice opportunity to allow the player to make up their own mind. However, the Prince decides that getting his♥♥♥♥♥♥wet is the prime directive and the game ends with a disappointing fizzle as you're forced to walk around doing some tree-prison gardening and undoing everything you've achieved in the space of a few minutes. (SPOILERS END HERE)	Apparently there was DLC for the console versions which layered an additional unsatisfying ending over the top in a desperate attempt to reach for a conclusion, but they didn't release that on PC so ♥♥♥♥ 'em.

												So another one of the new Prince of Persia gen games. I gotta say right outta the start that yes, I am a bit dissapointed about the difficulty level.  The game series carries quite a legacy and reputation, the prince series was one of the few games that taught me to have fun with a game even when sometimes is infuriatingly difficult.Most people say that Dark souls gave them back something they really missed from 2D games, actual hard challenge, to me that game was "Prince of Persia 3D" (the Mattel one) it was so hard to advance and at the same time so adicting because of the combat system and the feeling of achieving something every level you completed.So OK this one is easy, insultingly easy for any game actually (and more so for a PoP) since Elika (your partner) ALWAYS saves you, does not matter if you fall of a cliff or are about to have a sword jabbedd on your♥♥♥♥♥for sucking at combat SHE. 												A gorgeous, and somewhat casual, experience.  This is a shining example of how far the 'norm' of game design has evolved.  Once an brutal game untimely demises, then a game about rewinding said demises, now a game where you cannot die whatsoever.  This is definitely a game more about an experience than a "game" in the traditional sense of the word; 'Passive Beauty' is a good way to put it.  There isn't any real urgency felt as you deftly navigate the worlds and bosses, but it lets you absorb more of the visual artistic grandeur that lies in this world.  The characters begin to show some semblance of depth and witty banter, but I wish the story-telling matched the artful execution of the world.  In the end it's as lighthearted as the death-free combat, which is too bad, because it's the weakest link in this otherwise stellar reboot.

												The 2008 entry in the Prince of Persia series has a strong visual aesthetic and an impressive pedigree, but lacks gameplay worthy of either. At first glance, the ruins-crawling action seems to be on par with other standouts of the genre, but the gameplay quickly begins to feel repetitive and linear. The platforming is especially limited by the removal of the death mechanic - as soon as you miss a jump, you are transported back to the begining of the obstacle. This has a profound limit on the choices available to the player, as all paths are essentially reduced to on-rails quick time events. Combat is sparse and incredibly shallow, and since you can't die, it feels like more of a chore than anything. Most of the difficulty in this game comes from cheap tricks rather than clever design, and the handful of puzzles are all variations on using a lever to rotate things until they line up. Toss in an underwhelming story to boot, and you've got a frustratingly mediocre game.  C-

												The 2008 entry in the Prince of Persia series has a strong visual aesthetic and an impressive pedigree, but lacks gameplay worthy of either. At first glance, the ruins-crawling action seems to be on par with other standouts of the genre, but the gameplay quickly begins to feel repetitive and linear. The platforming is especially limited by the removal of the death mechanic - as soon as you miss a jump, you are transported back to the begining of the obstacle. Combat is sparse and incredibly shallow, and since you can't die, it feels like more of a chore than anything. Most of the difficulty in this game comes from cheap tricks rather than clever design, and the handful of puzzles are all variations on using a lever to rotate things until they line up. Toss in an underwhelming story to boot, and you've got a frustratingly mediocre game.  C-
